Review title: Two iconic characters justify women finally calling the shots
Review_body: Call it a chick flick, call it aggressive feminism, label it whatever you like, but "Thelma & Louise" is a classic story of female companionship and liberation that challenged what was and in many ways still is a male-centric movie industry. Roles for women in film have expanded over the years, but Thelma and Louise proved women can even be outlaws starring in a fugitive adventure thriller.Societal messages aside, however, it doesn't change the fact that Callie Khouri wrote a fantastic character-driven script with unexpected twists and turns and an unforeseeable ending. "Thelma & Louise" might be far from a blood-pumping fugitive crime thriller, but action and excitement is not what this film hangs its hat on.Even director Ridley Scott, who directed probably the greatest suspense movie with a female lead of all time in "Alien," recognizes that "Thelma & Louise" is relationship drama at its heart as two women discover themselves as they push each other over the edge.Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon star as the titular characters, one a suppressed housewife and another a chain-smoking waitress who plan a weekend getaway together only to end up trying to get away from the authorities after Louise shoots a man at a bar who tried to rape Thelma. After deciding there's no way to come clean of their crime, they run for the Mexico border as authorities (led by Harvey Keitel) try and track them down.Davis and Sarandon are an incredible duo playing the most detailed of characters. Davis as Thelma is the best of the two as she takes Thelma through a complete transformation from warm, acquiescent housewife looking to let loose to a fully committed armed criminal. Sarandon plays Louise as a colder, self-assured type who learns that she really doesn't have it all together. The two work in perfect balance creating strong, relatable and fascinating characters whose flaws make them so human.Not much has to be said for Scott's directing, he gives these characters the attention they need to blossom before us and does just enough to keep us guessing when they'll do some sudden and unpredictable.Yes, in this process of self-discovery, the girls both literally and symbolically give the middle finger to the male establishment. From shooting the abusive trickster that attempted to rape Thelma to Louise turning away her boyfriend (Michael Madsen) after he finds her and proposes to her, there's little sympathy for the male characters. Only Keitel's detective gets Khouri's vote as he defends the ladies (despite wanting to catch them) when a young Brad Pitt gets mixed up with them. Some of it might seem unnecessary such as the trucker who makes crude gestures to them along the highway, but considering Hollywood's abuse of the femme fatale, innocent girl and other female thriller/adventure genre archetypes, I'd say it's a fair trade, especially when these characters are actually very thoughtfully conceived. ~Steven CVisit my site at http://moviemusereviews.blogspot.com

Review title: "You said you and me was gonna get outta town and for once just really let our hair down. Well darlin', look out 'cause my hair is comin' down!"
Review_body: Thelma & Louise was made around the time when Ridley Scott, a foremost visual stylist, trendsetter of cyberpunk and atmospheric epics, was beginning to make films with contemporary settings to prove his capability of producing good work without the aid of special effects. It reveals the perceived untapped talent of Scott for high-spirited humor and pulsating American visuals. He reimagines the buddy film with such novelty and vitality that the genre gives an absolutely fresh impression. He discovered unforeseen assets within both of its stars, Sarandon and Davis, who are artlessly paired as the lively and unique title characters.Thelma & Louise also seemed to come at a time when Hollywood liked hard-hitting social conflict in the form of epic journeys through the country...Wild at Heart, Kalifornia, Natural Born Killers. Since the earliest movies, train travel was a popular motif, due to cinema's fascination with movement. When cars and motorbikes became more widespread, movement could be intimately connected with a character's individual development, and from the 1940s onwards, outsiders were continually portrayed as motorized nomads. Similar to the western, the road movie generally concentrates on solitary men who only feel free if they're in constant and restless movement.This classic picture is the version of that genre that either hadn't been made yet or in a way that reached people. Its central voyagers are renegades from an oppressive, male-dominated culture. They become intoxicated with freedom from double standards, fragile egos that must be gratified at the expense of their personal feelings, meaningless tradition, that they defy any and every rule they find themselves theoretically or practically confronting. From our introduction to this meek, submissive housewife and struggling waitress to their evolution to heat-packing fugitives impulsively destroying gas trucks, we've witnessed an epic journey in some sense on par with Ridley's literal epics. Increasingly more desperate, yet increasingly less confined, they show their true primal colors and awaken to themselves. One of them encapsulates it quite well in her own predisposed context: "You've always been crazy, this is just the first chance you've had to express yourself."The film develops a double perspective. The first follows the two best friends, who become more daring, more independent and less tolerant with every obstacle that crosses their path. Thelma begins to get the hang of being free and getting her own way. She locks a policeman into his own trunk at gunpoint when he tries to arrest them, and then blows up a petrol tanker when the driver directs a stream of sexist comments at them as he drives by. The second perspective shows the police investigations. Detective Slocumb's a sensitive cop who suspects the truth and tries to mediate, but he's powerless to stop the machinery of the FBI once it begins to roll. Frankly, this just seems like a point-counterpoint argument, where the filmmakers feel compelled to flesh out one male character as a non-chauvinistic guardian angel, an anomaly discounting potential grounds for accusations of an offensive stereotyping of men. The story would've been sufficiently effective were it to purely follow the two protagonists on their own subjective excursion. We understand why they would view men this way. Did Schrader feel compelled to supplement an altruistic black character to Taxi Driver to offset Travis' racism?Nevertheless, Keitel's scenes are very strong. Early on, he has an unusually strong scene where he questions a waitress at the club where the two women commit their first crime. Whether or not his character's established for said reasons, his characterization's not that shallow. Keitel gives it as many dimensions as he has the allotment to. The interaction of the cast is predominantly very engaging. Ridley seems not only to see his landscape, his visual style, but the essential nature of his leads, and the difference between moments which connect with that essence and don't, and whether or not Davis and Sarandon are always authentic or not---again I think that has more to do with the sometimes mawkish writing---they connect to their deepest resources, trust the moment, even when it may feel hackneyed. Their dynamic between each other, both on-screen and subtextually, is always handled sincerely and sensitively.And yet, I think we're only offered maybe three or four complex and layered characters in all, who undergo change throughout the plot, while the rest are eyeroll-inducing stereotypes of some degree of dirty, chauvinistic, beer-bellied men and other stock characters who unconsciously act antagonistically upon the two main characters virtually like an exploitation film. The essential flaw of Thelma & Louise is that it attempts to straddle the line between the two renegades' subjective immersion in their liberation and the realities of the outside world. With realistic characters who intermingle with total clichés, it becomes alternately a social issue drama that periodically doubles back on itself, and a fascinating road movie about self-actualization.Regardless, it undoubtedly touched audiences very deeply and has earned its status as a contemporary classic for that reason. The elements of Thelma & Louise that are effective are extremely effective, to the point that its minor shortcomings can be swiftly excused in the bigger scheme of it. I'm still uncertain of the last shot. It's a freeze frame that fades to white, which is fine, except it does so with ungainly hurriedness. I can't help but agree with Ebert that it's disconcerting to become engaged in a movie that takes 128 minutes to bring you to a conclusion that its makers seem to be anxious about. But fading to white doesn't stop it from having happened as the conclusion, and it's a beautiful example, in terms of our two main characters, of high romance and how to end a story. What matters is not the tying up of loose ends, but the ultimate reaction to the whole sequence of events.

I was surprised to find out that this is not based on real life events. People tend to talk about this film and these two women in a way that makes them seem real. They get mentioned a lot along with Bonnie and Clyde or the Wild Bunch. As if they were real, which is a huge vote for the film's advantage. Though I'm not exactly surprised that many people might be operating under the same assumption as I was. Because the whole film has a feel of real life to it. The way the events play out, the natural progression of conclusions and happenings, seems so logically random that it could very well have happened.As for the film as cinema, it's very good. The best way to describe the style would be to say that it's Ridley Scott emulating Quentin Tarantino. Though, perhaps that's simply because the film has Michael Madsen and Harvey Keitel. That always helps. Nevertheless, it has a really good grasp on the classic Americana style, with great love for open roads, gas stations, bars, stetsons and sheriffs.But, what really makes the film work are the two leading actresses. Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon are both fantastic as Thelma and Louise, respectively. Both are given very good, fetching characters, but what I really like is how they evolve during the course of the film. Initially Thelma is the meeker one, while Louise has a more aggressive attitude towards life in general. But, both have their high and low points, and when they are low, the other is able to pick up the slack and keep them going, both in their own way. Two beautiful characters and the perfect duo.Thelma & Louise is a great film to check out if you like Americana, crime duos, excellent drama with a good sense of humour, chases, strong female characters or just fine cinema in general.

Review title: Girls night out gone bad - mostly excellent entertainment
Review_body: If you can imagine a blend of "9 to 5", "Smokey and the Bandit" and "Bonnie and Clyde", you should come up with an approximation of "Thelma and Louise": a mix of adventure, humor and comrade in the style of the Bert Reynold's chase movies, and getting even with the stereotypical men who try to abuse, control or recapture these two women intent to enjoy a short escape from their boring lives. The possession of a pistol or two and some daredevil driving enables them to silence or elude most of the men who want to abuse or capture them or simply have fun with them. Clearly, Louise and Thelma initially have very different attitudes toward the strange men who try to seduce them. Loiuse makes it loud and clear she wants no part of these amorous come ons, whereas Thelma, especially after a few drinks, is often flirtatious and sometimes willing. But, Thelma eventually learns that fooling around with strange men can have traumatic consequences, and joins Louise in rebuffing further come ons. According to the DVD commentary, many in audiences cheered or clapped when Thelma's would be rapist is shot dead by Louise after making threatening remarks in the aftermath of Louise's breakup of the rape attempt. This clearly confirms what we may conclude from the popularity of confrontational westerns and action movies; that lethal vigilante justice, when done in appropriate circumstances, is considered justified by the majority of people, regardless of what the legal system thinks and does.One gets the impression that even if this duo didn't face probable long prison terms, they might have become permanent runaways from their unsatisfying lives. It is significant that neither had children, which may have alleviated some of their dissatisfaction, and which made their overblown girls night out adventure gone bad practical. The fact that both women were often foul mouthed, smoked and occasionally went to seedy bars turns off some viewers, who label them as brainless white trash who perhaps deserved some of the misadventures they suffered in their attempt at a short escape from their boring lives.Brad Pitt and Michael Madison provide two handsome hunks for female viewers to drool over, though very different. Brad represents the perfect con man who exploits naive vulnerable women both sexually and financially. He is the perfect bad boy for Thelma to find release in. Michael represents a man who isn't willing to settle down to a permanent one on one relationship, but who is willing to make occasional sacrifices for the women he has relationships with.The ending seems appropriate for this duo. Like Bonnie and Clyde, the pair eventually knew that they were doomed to long prison sentences and perhaps lethal injection, or to die in a shootout, car accident or by their own device. Like Bonnie and Clyde, they were prepared to try to elude their pursuers for as long as possible, and then to engineer their deaths if capture seemed imminently certain.

For starters - There were 2 things (yes, only 2) that I didn't like about Thelma & Louise.(1) Its finale (which sucked).And, yes - (2) Brad Pitt (who sucked, as well).But, with that all said, I must honestly admit that whenever it comes to the portrayal of a truly deceitful piece of slime (like J.D.), Brad Pitt is, by far, a true champion of champions.Anyways - Since I'm already convinced that everyone out there surely knows (all too well) the basic story of Thelma & Louise, there really doesn't seem to be a whole lot of sense for me to bother to repeat it again (for, like, about the umpteenth frickin' time, I'm sure).But, in a nutshell.... When it came to suspense and comedy, I found that these 2 elements mixed surprisingly well in this film about 2 gal-pals (living troubled, caged lives) whose 2-day getaway to a mountain retreat ends up escalating into a literal non-stop crime-spree (beginning with the committing of a murder). And, at this point Thelma and Louise were, of course, forced to hightail it for their lives as the law closed in on them, but fast.You know, I really must hand it to Director Ridley Scott on this one. He certainly hit the jackpot with this "Slick-Chick-Buddy-Flick", although it did become a tad predictable as the story progressed. I mean, when you really think about it, Thelma & Louise rarely ventured too far off the track of the all-too-familiar "road-movie" trail.But, with that all said and done - Thelma & Louise was, indeed, an exhilarating, little "joy-ride-of-a-movie", even though it could have, but did not (contrary to what others might think) go out in a blaze of glory.

Review title: There is a lot to like about this film
Review_body: Thelma & Louise (1991) is a movie I recently rewatched on Tubi and tells the tale of best friends looking to an enjoy a girl's trip. When a man gets too assertive one drunken night, one of the ladies with a troubled past shoots and kills him. They go on the run from the police in a desperate attempt to get to Mexico. Will they start a new life in Mexico or will the police hunt them down and capture them? This movie is directed by Ridley Scott (Bladerunner) and stars Susan Sarandon (Dead Man Walking), Geena Davis (Long Kiss Goodnight), Harvey Keitel (Pulp Fiction), Michael Madsen (Kill Bill) and Brad Pitt (Se7en). The cast and acting in this is awesome, as was the writing in terms of character establishment and dialogue. The circumstances were fun and hilarious at the same time. Davis really nailed her naïve and frustrating character. The attire and settings in this were perfect and I also loved the hairstyles. It's also easy to appreciate the ending as both tragic and triumphant. There is a lot to like about this film and I would score this a 10/10.

Review title: "Thelma & Louise" - These Girls Just Want To Have Fun... And Raise Some Hell, Too...
Review_body: Like the genre it ultimately upended, 1991's "Thelma & Louise" is an outlaw road movie that's full of twists and turns, some expected, some totally unexpected. Like most road movies, there are shots of a single vehicle on lonely stretches of highway and expansive shots of the American heartland, but right away what separates it from any film before it is its uniquely feminist slant.As a male viewer who has long embraced "Thelma & Louise" and also understood its underlying key themes, I am often hesitant - more like, completely unwilling - to ever call the film a pure "feminist picture" (or more derisively, to the film's detractor's, at least, "feminist propaganda"), I see it more as the ultimate expression of freedom and empowerment. It could have had two male leads and still have the same message (i.e., "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid"), but instead the film is about two women, so that almost immediately gives it an edge over anything that came before it - since nothing like it had ever been done before, and nothing like it has ever really been seen since."Thelma & Louse" is about two Arkansas women - Louise Sawyer and Thelma Dickinson (Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis, respectively, in performances that earned both of them shared Academy Award nominations for Best Actress and have a wonderfully organic screen chemistry) - whose weekend getaway is soured by a tragic encounter at a local honky-tonk bar, and both women wind up on the lam as a result.But of course, it's much more complicated than that.First-time screenwriter Callie Khouri's Oscar-winning script shows both Thelma and Louise caught in dead-end existences and desperately yearning for some kind of escape. Louise is a waitress at a diner who's in a relationship with Jimmy Lennox (Michael Madsen), a traveling musician who's afraid to commit to something more serious. Scatterbrained Thelma is married to the controlling, dim-witted chauvinist Darryl Dickinson (a hilariously dorky Christopher McDonald), who inflates his own self-importance as the regional sales manager for a local carpet company.So, yes, "Thelma & Louise" has a unique female perspective, and it's not particularly kind to a lot of its male characters. But it is not simple man-bashing (as many of the film's most vocal detractors so furiously claim) and it is not steeped in anger toward the male half of the species, as the ladies are aided by two sympathetic male characters - Louise's boyfriend Jimmy, who finally comes through for her just as she seems at her most liberated, and Hal Slocumb (Harvey Keitel), the Arkansas state police detective who becomes intimately involved in the women's plight. And of course, who can forget J. D. (Brad Pitt, in his ab-baring breakthrough performance), the good-looking, smooth-talking hustler who gives Thelma the night of her life between the sheets?Despite being written from a female perspective, "Thelma & Louise" was directed by a man, Britisher Ridley Scott, who gave us "Alien" (1979), which introduced Sigourney Weaver to the world as the first bona-fide action heroine. Additionally, Scott's films afterward, from "Blade Runner" (1982) all the way up to "Thelma & Louse" and beyond, have always had strong female characters that are central to the film's proceedings. Scott, a visual artist with a lush visual sense, also brings his unique English eye to the American West, so that the expansive vistas that we shallow Yanks often take for granted are given an entirely new visual appeal courtesy of both Scott and cinematographer Adrian Biddle.And lastly, there's that ending. I was actually unaware of the controversy over this film's climatic final shot until just recently. I've personally never seen anything wrong with it and have always believed it to be the most appropriate conclusion that this film could ever possibly have. Remember what I said about "Thelma & Louise's" underlying themes of liberation and escape? Yeah, that final shot just about sums it up. It was a brave final freeze-frame moment that shows that these two women, who we come to love and care about so much, and share such an incredible adventure (rife with danger, romance, tension, and hilarious mishaps) with have indeed made their "final escape" and are at last "free.""Thelma & Louise" has earned its place as a cinematic landmark, despite any glaring imperfections that it might share. All the praise it has earned at the time of its release and even long afterward, is surely and richly deserved. It's thrilling, action-packed, hilarious, and is just an overall good time at the movies.Still, in the end, though - These Girls Just Want To Have Fun, And Raise Some Hell, Too.9/10.

All the supposed controversy (i.e. hype) surrounding the release of Ridley Scott's high-octane road film never took into account how shallow and predictable it is. Calling the movie a male-bashing chick flick doesn't hide the fact that it is, transparently, just that: an otherwise routine, gender-bent buddy film, with all the expected clichés intact. Yes, the men are all two-dimensional stereotypes (good cop, bad cowboy, confused boyfriend, insensitive husband), but the two title characters are equally insubstantial, and the inevitable (and again, predictable) merging of their contrary personalities is finally achieved in a convenient, unresolved freeze-frame non-climax designed to avoid the necessity of a genuine ending.Notice how any remorse over the killing that inaugurates their crime spree only lasts a scene or two: convention demands that they be girls who just want to have fun, and because all their (male) targets are cartoon jerks every act of violence is not only justified, but commendable. It might have been interesting to show them blowing away, in cold blood, an innocent bystander of the opposite sex, but that would only jeopardize the contrived sympathy built into their roles.Lively performances by Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis aren't enough to camouflage the formula, and at any rate both actresses are lost behind all the pretty scenery, photographed not unlike an ad for Levi jeans: only another example of how artificial the film is.

To escape the unrelenting dullness of their everyday lives, two middle aged Southern women head out on a vacation together. Thelma is a ditsy, innocent homebody married to an unlikeable car salesman. Louise is smart, worldly, distrusting, and a careful planner who works as a waitress.The story starts off routinely as their road trip begins, but takes a non-routine turn when an incident occurs at a restaurant. From then on, the story gradually evolves into a majestic odyssey built on a foreboding sense of desperation, as the two women drive ever westward, through the rugged badlands of the American Southwest. Indeed, this film reminds me a lot of the 1973 classic "Badlands"; except that, as seekers of freedom, Thelma and Louise are far more sympathetic than the two lead characters in the earlier film.Both Geena Davis as Thelma, and Susan Sarandon as Louise, give terrific performances. They imbue their characters with complex traits that present Thelma and Louise as vibrant and believable, flawed but very human. In support roles, Harvey Keitel as the main detective and Brad Pitt as a drifter named J.D. enhance the film's overall quality of acting.Dialogue lends credible support to the story's characterizations, like when Thelma asks J.D. about his previous petty robbery experience. J.D. purrs in an oh-so-non-threatening way: "Well now, I've always believed that if done properly, armed robbery doesn't have to be a totally unpleasant experience". And Thelma's nature is such that her encounter with J.D. foreshadows the film's ending, which is both emotional and noble.Filled with mostly country/western music, the film exudes a mournful tone. I particularly like the songs "Part Of You, Part Of Me" by Glenn Frey, and "The Ballad Of Lucy Jordan" by Marianne Faithful.If the film has a weakness it is a plot that keeps reverting back to the police investigation, and therefore to the men in the two ladies' lives. I could thus have wished for less time on long-distance phone conversations and police questioning, and more time with the two central characters and their on-the-road adventure."Thelma & Louise" is a very American-type film, filled with dirt roads, open highway, expansive landscapes, and two likable women in search of freedom and self discovery. Technically well made, the film has both entertainment value and thematic depth.

Review title: A rare moment in cinema of the total rejection of the rule of law and patriarchy
Review_body: The road movie is traditionally a male genre, relying on the sense of freedom and independence that having one's own transport provides and which has usually been the privilege of men What is innovatory about "Thelma & Louise" is the way it reequips the genre for women Thelma (Geena Davis) is a housewife trapped in a meaningless marriage, Louise (Susan Sarandon) is a waitress in a not very significant relationship They decide to give themselves a little space by taking off for a weekend But when Louise shoots a man who is trying to rape Thelma, they are precipitated into a far more radical break with their past lives The setting of action in the American southwest and the acts of outlawry the women are obliged to commit in order to keep on the run give the film some of the feel of a Western What makes it nevertheless a women's film is that the relationship between the two principals is at the center of the story The various men they encounter, both the ones they leave behind and those they meet on the road have less importance for Thelma and Louise than the two women do for each otherPredictably, the film met with hostility from some male viewers, on the grounds that the men were caricatured and that the film encouraged violence

Review title: One of Ridley Scott's best films.
Review_body: An Arkansas Waitress Louise (Oscar-Winner:Susan Sarandon) and an bored housewife Thelma (Oscar-Winner:Geena Davis) are going camping for the weekend. Which these two woman only wants to relax and have some fun. But their weekend trip turns deadly serious, when Thelma is nearly raped by an drunk redneck (Timothy Carhart) and Louise shoots the rapist by self-defense. Instead of turning themselves in to the police and confess, they go on the run instead and trying to go to Mexico for an new life. But an determined police detective (Harvey Keitel) tries to find and help these two woman before they get into more trouble. But Thelma and Louise's trip to Mexico isn't easy, since the police are looking for them. Thelma got seduced by an charming thief (Brad Pitt), who stolen their money to start all over again. Thelma and Louise have to turn to crime by trying to reach their destination. But this detective, police and the FBI are closer of catching them.Directed by Ridley Scott (American Gangster, Black Hawk Down, Kingdom of Heaven) made an extremely entertaining, road film with plenty of humour, drama and heart as well. Sarandon and Davis gives excellent Oscar nominated performances in this film. Which both actresses were nominated for Best Actress for their strong roles. The film also has fine supporting by Keitel, Pitt, Michael Madsen, Christopher McDonald and Stephen Tobolowsky. This road movie is certainly familiar but it's made uniquely by two lead performances, strong writing by Callie Khouri (Mad Money, Something to Talk About) and Scott's visual style received an Oscar Nomination for Best Director as well.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer and an good-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD has two interesting commentaries tracks. One by producer/director:Scott. Second one is by actresses Sarandon & Davis and Screenwriter:Khouri. DVD also has 30 minutes worth of Deleted/Extended Scenes and Alternate Ending with Director's Commentary. But this DVD is 2004 edition, which 2003 edition has an documentary and music videos as well. Which 2003 edition is now out of print. Khouri received an Oscar for Best Original Screenplay. This film also received two Oscar nominations for Cinematography from the late Adrian Biddle (Aliens, Event Horizon, V for Vendetta) and Best Editing for Oscar-Winner:Thom Noble (The Exorcist 3, Red Dawn, Witness). This is probably the funniest film of Scott's work and also the most touching as well. McDonald is a hoot as Thelma's sleazy husband. An young Catherine Keener appears as Keitel's wife in one of the deleted scenes of the DVD. Don't miss this incredible film. Panavision. (**** ½/*****).

Review title: "At least now I'm having some fun"
Review_body: Back in the 30s and 40s, there was a kind of movie known as the women's picture. These were typically romantic dramas told from a female perspective, and while they often featured headstrong intelligent women (at least by the standards of typical portrayals), they would often have some kind of moral at the end about being a loyal and obedient wife as a kind of final goal in a woman's life. It was a long time, even years after the era of women's lib that patriarchy in the movies began to be completely deconstructed. The subject of women driven to murder by the actions of men was not a new one when Thelma & Louise was made in 1991. But if you look at a picture like Play Misty for Me from two decades earlier, where a used woman becomes the antagonist in a Psycho-type thriller, or I Spit on your Grave (1978) in which a woman's revenge for being raped could only be shown in a lurid exploitation movie, we can see how far the perspective has had to shift.Thelma & Louise, brilliantly scripted by Callie Kouri, gives an explanation for violence by women towards men, and it does so with amazing simplicity. There are no explicit arguments made. No character makes an overt feminist statement – the closest it comes to that is a by-the-way reminder by Geena Davis to the abducted policeman to be nice to his wife. The message, as it were, is up there in the screen as the story takes place. And although the basic outline of Thelma & Louise is very much out-of-the-ordinary for most women, if you break it down moment by moment, the men they encounter and the exchanges they have are very much on the near side of normal.A lot of Thelma & Louise's power is in its magnificent cast. Both Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis have a remarkable realism that demonstrates a great rapport between the two characters. When they laugh together, it's the laughter of two friends. Sarandon is brilliant at keeping that mystery to her character – the secret in Louise's past is bubbling under the surface of her performance long before it is revealed to the audience. Davis does an excellent job of showing character development, growing from the sheltered housewife into an independent woman comfortable with her newfound criminality. And it's neat how her sense of playfulness remains somehow consistent even as she changes. There are plenty of decent supporting performances as well. Brad Pitt was obviously chosen primarily for his youthful good looks, but he can act with it. Michael Madsen is very good too, intimidating in his controlled anger, but radiating a presence that makes his attractiveness to Louise understandable.The movie is directed by that meticulous craftsman Ridley Scott. He manages the movement in the frame with expert control for the right effect. In the opening scenes, the camera follows Sarandon around the chaos of the café. As she moves into a backroom during her phone call to Davis, the movement in the background tails off but is kept going by the chef juggling a can, and then as she moves across further the backdrop becomes the tranquil fish tank. These natural-looking set-ups are carefully controlling the mood of the image. As this road movie progresses, the backgrounds become increasingly wide open and breathtakingly beautiful, in line with the spirits of its protagonists. Scott culminates all this with some wonderful stylisation in the final action sequence. The movie would be in danger of becoming overly technical if it wasn't for his almost constant focus on Davis and Sarandon's faces, such as their quiet smiles as they cross Monument Valley by night.For all its feminist modernity, as a type of movie, Thelma & Louise treads familiar ground. The story of sympathetic criminals running free across the country as fate closes in can be seen in such classics as High Sierra (1941), Bonnie and Clyde (1967) and Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969). Really, the only major difference here is that the criminals are both women, not a couple of male hoods or a gangster and his moll. And yet, all it takes is this simple gender substitution to speak volumes about the experience of women in this society. That it does so without resorting to sermonising, and keeping up a healthy feeling of fun, makes Thelma & Louise an outstanding motion picture.

Review title: Exciting, Sincere And Stylish Female Outlaws Road Movie
Review_body: Louise Sawyer and Thelma Dickinson are girlfriends in the Midwest who take a weekend trip together in Louise's green 1966 Ford Thunderbird. At a truckstop, a man tries to rape Thelma and Louise shoots him. Fugitives from justice, the girls head for Mexico, trying to figure out what to do and how to put things in perspective.This is a stylish, highly original, confrontational picture, with a great script by Callie Khouri, who won an Oscar. What I like most about it are the questions it asks - when Louise shoots the slimeball it's not in self-defence, but neither is it a premeditated act; he simply offends her so much that she decides to do it. This prompts both the characters and us to reflect on who they really are and what they really want to be (typified by the line, "We got what we settled for.") and taps into a rich vein of female emancipation. It works both as a fantasy outlaw story and as a thought-provoking drama. Louise is smart but uptight and Thelma is naive but kind-hearted, but they both seem very real, and Scott and his director of photography Adrian Biddle (both of whom are British) capture the endless American landscapes with abstract precision. Sarandon and Davis are both sensational, somehow intense and goofy simultaneously, and Keitel and Madsen are brilliantly cast against type as the sympathetic males (although for me Keitel's character is just a tad too compassionate for a detective). There are nice bits too by McDonald as Thelma's irredeemable husband Darryl, and a young Pitt as a cocksure cowboy. Scott was an interesting choice to make this movie, a world away from Blade Runner or Black Rain, but it was both a commercial and a critical hit for him, although it's the two stars' movie all the way. Sarandon in particular is riveting in this film, really living and breathing the character, and giving arguably her best performance in a long career of distinguished work. Shot in fabulous desert locations in Utah and Colorado, and featuring a fine albeit underused score by Hans Zimmer.

Really a classic chick flick. About two best friends named Thelma and Louise played respectively by Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon. Thelma has an abusive husband, Christopher McDonald while Louise is bored with her really decent boyfriend, Michael Madsen.As both women are wanting to go away for a weekend. Review title: Legendary grand slam of pure adventure, Best movie ever made.
Review_body: SPOILERS THROUGH:I have commented on a lot of pics but almost didn't want to comment on this mainly because it is my favorite picture and I doubt I could do the film justice with a few words.Thelma and Louise is amazing from start to finish. There is absolutely nothing to criticize in this movie, just about every scene is flawless. This movie, besides having created two of the most amazing joyful women in film history Gina Davis and Susan Sarandon(as well as a few others notably a slick, slow talking drifter named JD played by Brad Pitt in his breakout role) takes us on an a journey of joy, adventure, tragedy, adversity, triumph and friendship.They say a good movie leaves it's mark on your life, once in awhile a movie actually alters your life's course. To me it rates a 20 out of 10.SPOILERS:The ending, as tragic as it was, was the only way it COULD have ended. Although the sentimental part of me would love to see a part 2, the realistic part of me knows this one's better left alone as is. (Although,with Hollywood-who knows what could happen?) Absolutely wonderful acting by all. Perfect songs and musical score, that don't just capture the essence of the film, they become part of it.See this if you haven't,it is a majestic triumphant masterpiece. 10 of 10.

"Thelma and Louise" is all and none of the things as which it has been described. It is about the friendship between two women, about female independence and male sexism, but it is neither a simple "chick flick" nor a monument to feminism (although I have to admit that watching it can have an almost therapeutic effect when you've just about "had it" again with the male slightly-less-than-half of society). Most of the men that Thelma and Louise encounter are two-dimensional cartoon characters, but "Reservoir Dogs" and perpetual tough guys Harvey Keitel and Michael Madsen (of all people) are cast against stereotype. The movie also features some absolutely stunning pictures of the Southwestern scenery and mostly takes place on the road, but it is not just a "road movie" (feminist or otherwise). More than anything, this is a movie about the things that shape the way we are, and about the consequences of our actions. Had Thelma learned to use her brain before and not after their encounter with Harlan the rapist, she would have seen him for what he was and avoided him from the start. Had Louise not been raped herself, she would probably not have shot Harlan at being provoked by him, after the self-defense situation was already over. Impulse? Fate? Justifiable homicide? Hardly. Thoroughly understandable? Absolutely, at least from a woman's point of view.But above all else, it's a movie about two humans getting caught up in a maddening spiral of events that have taken on a life of their own - a perfect parable for what's happening all over the world, day in and day out. You set something in motion and from that moment on it's beyond your control. Thelma and Louise's only "triumph" is their acknowledgment that they have done this to themselves. They don't say so of course; but their final action says it for them. The plot could've also been one dimensional and uninteresting, but writer Callie Khouri again made of sparkle with inventive sequences, a solid mix of action, laughter and drama, and crackling dialogue. And the direction by cinematic director Ridley Scott is audacious. The last sequence is one of the most beautiful images in cinema, and it brought a bit of a tear to my eye. Whilst there are some laughs along the way to endure (such as the pair blowing up a foul-mouthed van drivers vehicle up), Thelma And Louise stands as a compelling and riveting drama.Overall rating: 8 out of 10.

Review title: Often thrilling, but the melodrama holds it back. Sarandon shines.
Review_body: It feels like Thelma & Louise's reputation precedes the film itself. It's another iconic film from the 1990s that I knew more from parodies and references. When I finally looked it up several years ago while I was getting into film, it surprised me that it was directed by Ridley Scott and starred Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon. While their identities are clearly on the film, the characters and themes seem to have transcended the stars' reputations. Scott's trademarks are definitely imprinted firmly here with his kinetic style of editing, great soundtrack and the humid cinematography where you can feel the heat from the screen. It's surprisingly cinematic. Unfortunately with two protagonists the story does go back and forth more than I'd like it to and it has a heavy melodrama that's involving but often too melancholic and this mood holds the film back quite a lot. The story does have its hits though and the best scenes involve Thelma and Louise's transformation such as when they apologetically put a cop in his trunk while they drive away. While Davis and Sarandon do share the film, Sarandon is the real highlight and gives a brilliant performance that feels truly genuine.7/10

But it don't make up for the rest unfortunately, and that ending so talked about over the years, you can't really feel the danger. As far as it being a feminist movie, I hope not. Like I said, these aren't great role models...

Review title: More than an exercise in male-bashing
Review_body: This is an important commercial film aimed at blue collar women who feel victimized by both society and the men in their lives. Directed by Ridley Scott, who directed the science fiction classics, Alien (1979) and Blade Runner (1982), Thelma and Louise is an on-the-lam chick flick (with chase scenes), a kind of femme Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969), somewhat akin to Wild at Heart (1990) and Natural Born Killers (1994) but without the gratuitous violence of those films. Ridley Scott walks the razor edge between femme-exploitation and serious social commentary. Incidentally, the script is by Callie Khouri who wrote Something to Talk About (1995) and Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002) which should give you an idea of how men are depicted here.Susan Sarandon is Louise, a thirty-something Arkansas waitress with an attitude and some emotional baggage, and Geena Davis is Thelma, a cloistered ingenue housewife with a yearning to breath free. Both do an outstanding job and carry the film from beginning to end. The characters they play are well-rounded and fully developed and sympathetic, in contrast to the men in the film who are for the most part merely clichés, or in the case of Darryl (Christopher McDonald), Thelma's boorish husband, or the troll-like truck driver, burlesques.I have never seen Geena Davis better. Her unique style is melded very well into a naive woman who never had a chance to express herself, but goes hog wild and seems a natural at it when the time comes. Sarandon is also at the top of her game and plays the crusty, worldly wise, vulnerable Louise with tenderness and understanding. Note, by the way, her pinned up in back hair-style, directly lifted from TV's Polly Holliday ("Kiss my grits!") who appeared as a waitress in the seventies sitcoms "Alice" and "Flo."Harvey Keitel plays the almost sympathetic cop, Hal Slocumb, and Brad Pitt appears as J. D., a sweet-talking twenty-something who gives Thelma the script for robbing 7-11s as he steals more than her libido.This movie works because it is funny and sad by turns and expresses the yearning we all have to be free of the restraints of society and its institutions (symbolized in the wide-open spaces of the American Southwest) while representing the on again, off again incompatibility of the male and female heart. The male-bashing is done with a touch of humor and the targets are richly deserving of what they get. The ending is perhaps too theatrical and frankly unrealistic, but opinions may differ.Best and most telling quick scene is when Thelma phones Darryl to see if he has found out about their escapades. Weasel-like, he is trying to help the cops locate them, but he is so transparent to her that all she has to do is hear his voice. "He knows," she says to Louise and hangs up.Best visual is when the black police helicopter appears suddenly, menacingly like a giant fly beneath the horizon of the Grand Canyon. Also excellent were the all those squad cars lined up like armored battalions aimed at the girls on the run.I also liked the scenes at the motel with J.D. and Louise's boyfriend. They were beautifully directed and cut, and very well conveyed by Sarandon and Davis, depicting two contrasting stages in male-female relationships.See this for Geena Davis because she was brilliant, vividly alive and never looked better.

How many tough female characters can you think of, in cinema history? If we're judging on 'action' and not REaction, then I could probably count mine on the fingers of one hand. Thelma and/or Louise would have to be included in and amongst them... Don't any guys be fooled into brushing it off as a 'chick flick', though, as the male characters are just as important to the story; and, in a pleasing surprise, not ALL unsympathetic scumbags - as I had half expected before I viewed... The whole thing demonstrates how women should be treated as equals. If you're a guy who doesn't think this already, it seems perfectly obvious to me that you have more problems than a film can fix, so you shouldn't be watching this in the first place...The ending isn't the only thing about this that's iconic (perhaps Brad Pitt, amongst other things, for you ladies!) and to accomplish the feat of connecting so resoundingly within only a decade and a half is extraordinary in itself. Some may wish for a more 'just' resolution, but both female characters realise that after the change, there's no going back...The movie never slows for scenes of quiet introspection about this 'bond' that they share, so I say this movie is less about friendship, and more about the extraordinary human resistance to hardship - given the obstacles that both women as individuals have to overcome. There will be those who shout: 'Girl Power'; but such dogged tenacity can be an inspiration to EITHER sex, and both Kietel and Madsen - in heartening 'sympathetic' roles - underline just what good can come from an understanding disposition...In a film like this, the dynamic between the two female leads should be a shoe-in for most eye-catching element; indeed, in most other films, it would be, as two great actresses do excellent work. Special mention to Ridley Scott, then, for managing to steal the movie himself with his broad direction. It oozes 'mass appeal', while never trivializing the sub-textual undercurrents that have been looked at time and time again. A neat trick for sure, and just maybe one example of why he tends to be forgiven when he has projects that aren't received so well... ('Legend' is one, for me... ) It's good that we have such types of lasting celluloid heroines, however few they are; and it's something that certainly makes 'Thelma & Louise' stand out; but don't let that obscure the fact that it's a cracking road movie on OTHER terms, also... !

Review title: Ridley Scott's dark comedy is both shocking and cynical, but incredibly entertaining
Review_body: Director Ridley Scott met his rise to stardom after his success with the science-fiction thriller 'Alien' in 1979, and his dystopian thriller masterpiece 'Blade Runner', although it didn't initially receive the proper recognition by critics or at the box office upon it's release. At the dawn of 90s, the awe-inspiring filmmaker decided to steer into another route aside from the sci-fi genre, and that is when he found the courage to tackle on some thought- provoking themes about society and feminism. His achievement is found here in this dark road-trip comedy starring Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis in their anti-heroine roles who are given a mouth full to say about society and it's uncouth treatment towards women, but perhaps not the most orthodox way for that matter. The film centers on Thelma Dickinson (played by Geena Davis), an Arkansas housewife living under the household of her manipulative husband Darryl (played by Christopher McDonald); and her best friend Louise Sawyer (played by Susan Sarandon), a waitress at a local diner who's dating kind-hearted musician Jimmy (played by Michael Madsen) who sadly doesn't have enough for her as his music career always have him on the road. Escaping from their boring and demented lives, Thelma and Louise decide to take a road trip in their 1966 Ford Thunderbird Convertible. Along the way, they stop at a local bar where Thelma meets a handsome young man who quickly turns dangerous when he tries to rape her. Catching him in the middle of act, Louise opens fire and kills the guy, leading to her and Thelma fleeing their hometown. Learning they are now wanted by the law enforcement, the women make a desperate attempt to flee to Mexico with Detective Hal Slocumb (played by Harvey Keital) hunting them down.If you are looking for a high-octane action thriller with gunfights and explosive special effects, then you are probably not at the right place. If you are looking a road-trip comedy with big laughs and charm, you're probably not at the right place either. Though there is some humor and cleverness to be encountered from it's two lead actresses, this road-trip flick has something much more provocative to say than just light-hearted entertaining set pieces. The movie centers on it's two titular character as journey across the country in search of a new life after becoming fed up of their sour lifestyle they endured from their constant maltreatment from the male crowd, and this all leads to a feministic atmosphere as these women fight for power over their lives. This also accounts to to some grim, but fascinating character studies. For instance, one scene involves Lousie imploring Thelma to find way to make it to Mexico without cruising through Texas due to her fear of being in the state after a horrifying experience left her traumatized. From there on, you begin to feel for both her and Thelma as you come to realize they have been victims of horrible crimes that left scars on them, and they won't heal. Although their cynical views on society and callous behavior don't make for the most likable characters, Ridley Scott does a pleasant job as providing them with a heart and humanity rather than savage criminals, and successfully maps a compelling character-driven plot up to it's shocking finale. Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis are both give endearing performances in their roles as does Harvey Keital as the Detective who hunts them down on their odyssey. Michael Madsen and Christopher McDonald are not bad, but not given a whole lot work with due to their limited screen time. One of the biggest surprises though, is the young and handsome Brad Pitt as the young heartthrob who acquired the attention of Thelma, and like most of his roles; he gets the job done.Thelma & Louise is a smart, outstanding work by visionary director Ridley Scott, with mesmerizing performances, an awe-inspiring direction driven by Scott's ingenuity, and an overall successful ability to tackle on thought-provoking subject matter. While the film does evoke a cynical atmosphere and shock value that probably won't be everyone's cup of tea, it's still incredibly entertaining.

Review title: Ridley Scott knows his way around multi-genre cinema.
Review_body: Thelma & Louise is a bonafide 90s classic, and it didn't have to make things overly complicated to get the message across: two women on the run over a self-defence killing and embarking on the road trip of a lifetime.This is one of Ridley Scott's finest films and an innovative-as-hell movie for 1991. It's character-driven drama at its finest.Thelma and Louise has earned its place in cinema history.

Review title: Wish I could say I felt better about this film{{Spoilers Possible}}
Review_body: When I first caught this movie at the campus movie theater(discount admission,can't beat that!),it was somewhat fresh off the movie theaters,not yet on video(this was 1991,of course)and the controversy that swirled around this film was still pretty fresh,so I went into watching this with some trepidation. I was a nineteen year old boy who had little to no clue about females(one could probably say that much hasn't changed for me),and what I knew about this film was that it was considered by some critics to be "mlae bashing" and unfair to men,stereotyping them as either rapists or abusers. After seeing this the first time,while I was impressed with the sharpness of the film's dialog,acting and unique story,I still came away feeling depressed,though I couldn't really put my finger on why,expect for the fact that the ending was quite depressing. As I found it,I didn't find this film to be THAT male-bashing or anti-dude. I just found it a downer,in short.Sixteen years later,watching it again on TV,I found myself not feeling a whole lot differently,which amazes me,since usually when I see a movie again after a gap of time,I usually find something about it that I didn't before. Precious little if anything did I find new about this show,save that I found that WHY I found this depressing was much more nebulous. It wasn't one thing,it was everything,chief among them the fact that the fate of these two for whom you've probably come to like or deign some sympathy for are INEVITIBLY destined for a tragic fate.The adventure that begins as a simple Girls' vacation between best friends Thelma Dickinson(Geena Davis,post-Oscar,pre-pre-pre "Commander in Chief") and Louise Sawyer(Susan Sarandon,kickin'it at forty-four,hot as ever and tough)turns into a fugitive run as the ladies avoid a rape,kill a guy,get robbed,hold at least two different men at gunpoint(one of whom is a highway patrolman)on the highway and do damage to an oil tanker. All the while,they're pursued by a feckless fed(HArvey Keitel,in what seems to be role #776 of a thousand),seduced by a wayward slikster(Brad Pitt in his first major role,shirtless nearly the whole time)and fretted over by the girls' respective boyfriends(Christopher MacDonald and Michael Madsen). As they keep on running from their lives,they start to realize there's no turning back as their bond gets stronger.I think it bears some repeating: while I believe this movie is basically well-done and captivating,the harrowing and depressing chain of events really strike me as being a delightful movie ONLY if you're some sort of nihilistic feminist with a slight streak of sociopath.IN sum,this movie--sporting impressive direction by Ridley Scott and a daring script by Callie Khouri--is what I'd call a downer. Not for any specific reason or quality,but for the whole total package.

"Thelma & Louise" is not only a classic road movie but also one of the most entertaining journeys to ever hit the big screen. Its delicious combination of drama, action and comedy is brilliantly balanced to create a story that delivers sufficient humour, warmth and exhilaration to ensure that its commentary about sexual oppression never gets so heavy-handed that it detracts from the enjoyment of watching this special film. Oscar-winning screenwriter Callie Khouri deserves great credit for achieving this balance and also for the quality of her script which is intelligent and witty and contains numerous quotable remarks.Timid housewife Thelma Dickinson (Geena Davis) and hardworking waitress Louise Sawyer (Susan Sarandon) take off on a weekend vacation together to have some fun and escape their tedious daily lives. Their trip begins well and they're soon in high spirits. Things change dramatically, however, after they stop at a roadside bar where Thelma has a few too many drinks and enjoys flirting with a local redneck who takes her out to the parking lot where he tries to rape her. Louise follows the couple outside and successfully rescues her friend by threatening the attacker with a gun. When the man continues to be verbally abusive, the keyed-up Louise shoots and kills him and the women immediately go on the run because Louise knows for sure that the police would never believe their account of what happened.The two women decide to head for a new life in Mexico and the police and the FBI gather information from Thelma's husband Darryl (Christopher McDonald). Louise contacts her boyfriend Jimmy (Michael Madsen) and he subsequently brings her life savings to her. On their travels the women meet a handsome drifter called J.D. (Brad Pitt) and Thelma spends a night with him in her motel room where he describes the method that he regularly uses for robbing convenience stores. Next day, Thelma's initial state of euphoria suddenly changes when she realises that J.D. has disappeared with all their money and so to compensate for the loss, she robs a convenience store using the same method she'd learnt from J.D.Later, an encounter with a state trooper ends when the women hold him at gunpoint and lock him in the trunk of his squad car and on another occasion, they take revenge on a tanker driver who persistently makes obscene gestures at them, by blowing up his entire rig. Their no-hold-barred journey then continues in the same vein until it eventually reaches its spectacular and very appropriate conclusion.With one exception, the men in "Thelma & Louise" are an appalling collection of characters whose conduct is portrayed as being the trigger for the women's need to escape and it's ironic that the times when the two friends feel most excited and powerful is after having indulged in the types of criminal actions which are most often perpetrated by men.Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis are magnificent in their roles as the two women who've both been treated very cruelly by men and the supporting performances from Brad Pitt, Michael Madsen and Harvey Keitel (as the only decent man featured) are all excellent. Christopher McDonald provides a lot of laughs with his over-the-top mannerisms and Keitel's reactions to them are equally funny."Thelma & Louise" with its wide open spaces and atmospheric music is visually very strong and intelligently paced. It's a marvellous piece of entertainment and unsurprisingly has maintained its popularity consistently over the years since its initial release.

You have to give it up for a movie that casts Michael Madsen as pretty much the only sane guy in existence. Thelma (Geena Davis) and Louise (Susan Sarandon) go off from their banal existences to a trip that heads up poop creek really REALLY fast. After shooting dead a would-be rapist, they both head for the hills where the law, personal freedom and, yes, Brad Pitt await! I hadn't seen this in quite a number of years, and it was great to come back to. I remembered a lot of it, but I noticed particularly this time the strong performances of not only of Davis and Sarandon, but of Harvey Keitel, Madsen (who is actually amazing), Pitt, and quite underplayingly, Christopher Mcdonald. Ridley Scott puts these elements all together in one explosive package.

Review title: I know I missed something here
Review_body: Two women toy with the idea of independence and end up running from the law, after killing dirtball/would-be-rapist.  I guess it's fun if you're into female-bonding, but I missed the point of this one.  If you like all your movie guys as plastic airheads, then this movie is highly recommended.

Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis shine in their roles as two unsatisfied women who go on the road to escape their doldrums of lives for a simple weekend. Tragedy strikes early, however, and soon Thelma and Louise are on the run from the authorities with really no direction to go.The acting here is very good with Sarandon and Davis playing their roles perfectly. It is impossible to think of any other actress being these two. Sarandon perfectly captures the dark past and ambitious feeling of the waiter Louise and Geena Davis is so charming and bubbly as Thelma, the housewife controlled by her demeaning husband. The supporting men here are strong as well, especially Harvey Keitel as a detective on their trail, Michael Madsen as Louise's boyfriend, and Brad Pitt in a star-making role as a sweet-talking hitchhiker.All the elements work well together but I think director Ridley Scott deserves a lot of praise for creating this type of movie into one that is now considered a classic after all these years. Scott paces the movie just right, perfectly cutting between the two women and the people on their trail. We also get some nice sentimental moments between Louise and her boyfriend Jimmy, who do love each other but cannot be together. This is a formulaic story but the movie mostly avoids being a formulaic movie. I must say I wasn't impressed with the ending, but for the most part I really enjoyed this story and got involved with the characters. As a fun joyride, though, Thelma and Louise has to be one of the best.

Though the film delivers a feminist message, it doesn't feel preachy.  So I wouldn't call this a "chick flick."  I don't really believe a "chick flick" genre exists, but for those guys who do--don't worry, you have nothing to worry about.  Plus, it's directed by Ridley Scott, so there's action elements scattered here and there.  There's a big truck explosion towards the end, since you can't have a Ridley Scott film without any explosions. It's just against Ridley's nature.  The story involves a studly but abusive man at a bar getting shot after attempting to rape Geena Davis and a greasy, perverted truck driver getting his truck blown up, but I still didn't feel the female screenwriter was heavy-handed in delivering her message about females being treated inferior to males in society, and her fantasy about females empowering themselves and overcoming the oppression that men put them through.  Because you really feel a connection to these characters--whether you're a man or woman--and you want to cheer for them every step of the way.  The cast is first-rate.  Susan Sarandon is superb as always, and so is Geena Davis--and man, is she HOTTT!!  My man Harvey Keitel is cool as the hard-nosed Arkansas detective.  Michael Madsen is also a really cool actor, and he's great as well, though he couldn't grasp a Southern accent.  I'll let that slide.  Chris McDonald delivers a delightfully farcical performance as Davis's aggressive but bumbling husband.  He delivers most of the laughs in the film.  I just felt the movie could've been trimmed about thirty minutes.  Plus, it's mainly dialogue-driven and it does tend to drag at points. Nevertheless it's funny, exciting, touching and one wild ride!  And it has a good message--not just about the roles of females in society but also about the power of friendship.  Unfortunately, I knew the ending before watching this movie today for the first time.  It has one of those landmark endings that everyone talks about--I'm just not going to mention it here because it would be considered a spoiler.  But I was still very entertained.  My score:  7 (out of 10)

Review title: Stunning drama with sensational acting and filming
Review_body: On a road trip, Thelma (Davis) and Louise (Sarandon) set out on the run from the police after committing murder.In 1992 the Oscars were dominated by Jonathan Demme's masterful The Silence of the Lambs, a cold mystery thriller with the most famous flesh eater of all time, Hannibal the Cannibal, played with such coldness and sophistication by Anthony Hopkins. The film also demonstrated a marvellously intellectual leading role to Jodie Foster, who beat two of the finest actresses in Hollywood to the coveted prize, Sarandon and Davis.The pair certainly cemented themselves in Hollywood with this film. A powerful leading duo who make this film what it is and whilst the conceptual nature of this film is fascinating, the American actresses make this film so.Sarandon's sharp and opinionated Louise thrives the film forward with her independent mindset. This is finely balanced against Davis' Thelma who holds back and questions the course of action and can never seem to think for herself. The balance in personalities and the emotional setback the pair go through justifies the Oscar nominations and add something deep and meaningful to this movie.This Ridley Scott picture is certainly powerful when looking at a real life perspective. The two leads escape their hard lives for a mountain trip but are sidetracked when Thelma gets raped in a bar car park. This controversial realism shows the balance of strong and weak with lust against desire to make t quite horrific in a sense and Scott isn't afraid to back down on the dialogue as cursing and a sharp bullet in the chest show. This act sets the film in motion and from here on in, this is a fascinating changing drama.This dramatic implementation of murder resolves the in-depth motive of the mountain trip to be changed into a desperate journey to safety as the pair explores their options.This dramatic change and realistic example of drama is one of the main reasons why this picture won n Oscar for best original screenplay as the tension and drama really sink in.The pace continues to mount as the friends descend to desperation in order to survive. After a delightfully amusing Brad Pitt makes a mockery of the pair does the real tension set in and soon the pair cross the boundaries of innocence as they explore their options and descend to illegal activities, with the store robbery a highlight.What is also impressive about this picture is the cinematography. The sweeping settings are well used to add to the feeling of freedom when the pair enters the Grand Canyon and the operating factory the pair drive through to elude the cops. The filming is staggering and is a wonder right up until the infamous final shot, which is arguably shot of the film as Scott goes for all out in gasping climax.With Sarandon and Davis on top form and with the stunning settings and dramatically tense and exciting plot, this picture is a must see.

Review title: Thelma and Louise Are Aging Poorly
Review_body: Thelma and Louise is a star vehicle for Davis and Sarandon, and and a soapbox for "women as victims" feminism.  In the movie all men are pigs, either stupid and selfish or brutal and violent (or both), and they mostly get their commupance at the hands of Thelma and Louise of whom there are enumerable close ups.  For an action/buddy movie the pacing is surprisingly slow, the dialogue ponderous, and the characters one-dimensional.  Thelma and Louise are aging poorly, and I gave it only a 5.

From Ridley Scott, the man who created dark and brooding sci fi masterpieces like Alien and Blade Runner comes a story about two southern housewives on the run from the law in the wide open midwest. Wait what? The name Ridley Scott is synonymous with darkly innovative science fiction so it's always weird to see his name attached the most unlikely of projects such as Thelma & Louise. I'm not complaining though because Ridley Scott or not, this movie is actually pretty good. Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon play Thelma and Louise, respectively. The movie gives us little initial backstory, but we know enough to get into the story. We can figure that they are two long time friends who have probably lived in the same little old town for their entire lives. What we know for sure is that they have had enough and now figure it is time to hit the road and seek some real adventure. So they do just that and the main plot excitingly kicks off. Everything is going great until they stop at a bar and one of the patrons starts to get a little too friendly with Thelma. Before anything terrible can happen, Louise saves her friend and the whole situation seems to be resolved until the rapist gives a little too much lip and Louise shoots him dead. The two panic stricken ladies flee the scene and after calming down they resolve to flee to Mexico. But of course the law gets involved and they are right on their tail for the majority of the film. It's definitely a fun story with its fill of excitement and adventure.The two leading ladies are characterized very well as the anti-heroes, and Sarandon and Davis pull off these roles excellently. They're a joy to watch and their chemistry is riveting. Their progression through the movie is also very interesting to watch as they flip flop roles throughout the film. At times Thelma will be the strong and controlled type, but at other times Louise will have to take over this role while Thelma gets her head on straight. The mishaps these two have on their way to Mexico present increasingly more complex dilemmas to work out of, and the excellent performances of Sarandon and Davis keep it entertaining most of the way through. The rest of the cast, for what it's worth, are good too but the main focus is on Thelma and Louise. This film seems very anti-male, however. Pretty much every male character in this movie is either a scoundrel, a liar, or a cheater. I guess that's fitting for a movie that focuses on two strong willed and self sufficient women, but I had to scratch my head and think, jeez... we're not all this bad are we? But at least you can clearly see the film's intentions.Thelma & Louise won an Oscar for best original screenplay and I can't argue too much with that. It's a well deserved Oscar because the dialouge in this is definitely something worth noting. It captures the mindsets and attitudes of the midwest population very well. The script has a lot of life to it and even if Thelma and Louise were the only two characters in the film it would still be entertaining for a while to watch them interact. As for the story itself, most of what happens keeps it interesting, but it seems to drag towards the middle and becomes somewhat tedious. But it is all worth it when you reach the end where you realize what might have seemed tedious before was actually just build up for a riveting ending that sent chills through my body. The ending is absolutely fantastic and is no shorter or longer than it needed to be.Thelma & Louise is a worthwhile watch. It's a fun adventure story with two great main characters who you will fall in love with and be rooting for the entire movie. The portrayal of men is a little discerning, but it's also fitting to some of the central focus of the film. The film may seem redundant towards the middle but it's all worth it in the end, making this movie an all around good ride.

Their interactivity is one of the best ever done in a major film like this.Scott has always tried being a visual worker, here his camera is as strong as in Alien or Black Rain, but not as good as Blade Runner.  The editing is also strong enough to keep the movie going in all of two hours.Feminism in a film like this is a touchy subject.  While on the surface the idea is proposed of feminine strength (much like Tootsie), but underneath is a social commentary on socially unacceptable men.  J.D. and Thelma's husband represent both the obvious and not-so-obvious sides of the matter.Overall, better than average film with enough strength to punch through whatever weakness the script--Brad Pitt in particular--can throw at it.  3.5 out of 5 stars.

Review title: Absent the Attitude, Still a Good Movie: SPOILER?
Review_body: Thelma & Louise was a sensation when it came out, partly because it was a female buddy movie with a distinctly feminist attitude. Twenty years later, the feminist underpinning is less appealing. Murder, robbery, overpowering a police officer, exploding a gas truck because the driver is a male chauvinist pig seem distinctly less admirable than they might have been in 1991. But Geena Davis as Thelma and Susan Sarandon as Louise are excellent actors and inhabit their roles: Geena as a naive, sexy and more-than-slightly ditsy housewife dominated by an overbearing husband and Louise as a street-wise waitress anxious for more than life has given her. The presence of Brad Pitt as a handsome, hitchhiking thief provides a bit of audience appeal, though any good-looking young actor could have done as well. After Louise murders a bar fly who attempts to rape a drunken Thelma outside the bar, they begin a flight from the cops that becomes increasingly urgent once Thelma robs a store at gunpoint to restore some of the money stolen from her after sex by the handsome hitchhiker. Ultimately cornered in the desert on the edge of a canyon, Thelma persuades Louise to go out in defiant style by driving off the cliff. Despite the desire of some of the film's fans for a happier outcome, it's an appropriate ending for a feminist fantasy film that remains hugely entertaining, largely on the strength of outstanding performances by the two principals and a story which, however improbable, equals a lot of male buddy movies which preceded 'Thelma and Louise".

Having just watched Thelma & Louise for the first time, nearly thirty years after its release, I feel compelled to jot down a few observations. First, the shooting of the rapist was not self-defense, because the two women were secure when the shooting took place. It was an act of execution, apparently for the guy´s provocation (¨Suck my c**k!¨), but more likely it was a projection of what Louise´s rapist from Texas deserved, at least in her mind. Viewed that way, it was a revenge execution for the harm that she suffered at the hands of an equally despicable man.Second, despite the many interpretations according to which this is a feminist classic, I must demur. The problem is that the women do not prevail by changing the world but by leaving it. The world at the end of the film contains two fewer women than it did at the beginning. More importantly, two lively and bold women have disappeared from the face of the earth. They did not fit into the male-dominated world, and so they left it.Third, because not all depictions of all men in this film are negative (the Harvey Keitel character is a good example of a man who attempts to understand and help the women, to the best of his ability), I do not think that this is an anti-male screed, as some have complained. The Michael Madsen character, too, seems to be a basically decent guy, who appears even to love Louise.Fourth, because the women make blunder after blunder, this film may reinforce the stereotype according to which women are less intelligent than men. In other words, without being misogynistic, Thelma & Louise does nothing to counter the age-old prejudices according to which women are inferior, and important decisions should be left to the men folk.All of that said, the pace, cinematography, acting, directing, and everything else are really good. It is an action film, above all, but can be read metaphorically as well. Thelma & Louise ultimately poses the question: is it better to live large for a short time, or survive much longer by docilely accepting what those in power (primarily men) expect one to do?

Two women flying by the seat of their pants won't end well if they're both terrible decision makers. This fun road trip turns into a Bonnie & Clyde-esque situation. Except Bonnie & Clyde was an adventure-filled whirlwind of romance, daring, and careful planning, while Thelma and Louise repeatedly make terrible and often illogical actions. They begin as very relatable women who need a change from their mundane lives, but they begin to develop into exactly the people that the police believe they are, and they relish in it almost to the point of psychosis.The whole cast performs well, but the movie failed to logically or emotionally hook me into Thelma and Louise's flippant acceptance of their new life. If you can't follow the transition, you won't enjoy this movie as the fun and carefree adventure that it was intended to be.

Overlooking for a moment THELMA AND LOUISE's blatant sexism: all the men are liars, cheats, rapists or morons; all the women are "Victims" with a capital "V" -- even as they kill, rob and vandalize their way across the US Southwest.And setting aside that Callie Khouri's Oscar-winning screenplay is nothing but a collection of tired cliches from two separate genres: the male buddy film ("bang bang boom boom) and the whiny chick flick: "weep weep sob sob").The question that comes to my mind is why this is, in any way, considered to be a "feminist" film. These are, after all, two of the stupidest women who ever stumbled across a movie screen. The are not in control of their lives as some have suggested: they are on the run from the law, on the run from taking responsibility for their own reckless and criminal behavior. They are stupid and they are cowardly. They are not role models, or even typical "oppressed" women. But because they chose men as their victims -- and stand up to the men only when they have guns in their hands -- they are applauded for their boldness. Two men who only terrorized women would be dismissed as creeps.It is one of the perversions of feminism that women measure their success by the standards set by men, even when they would otherwise condescendingly criticize that behavior as being negative and/or macho. In this case, adventures that would be mocked as sexist if perpetrated by men, are embraced as being empowering when committed by women. Also, it is the added dynamics of the situations: if Thelma and Louis victimized any women, their defenders would not praise their actions because it would be a violation of the "sisterhood." It is only the targeting of male victims that earn this film its praise: Surely pure, unadulterated sexism -- or is that feminism? It's hard to tell the difference.Not that THELMA AND LOUISE isn't without good points. Anyone who appreciates Susan Sarandon's acting skills and/or Brad Pitt's sculpted torso will be gratified. Perhaps the only real star of the film, however, is Thelma's mint 1966 Thunderbird convertible; a gorgeous classic that deserves a fate far better than what is served up by this pathetically mediocre film. When Louise and Thelma meet their ultimate demise, one wishes they had had the common decency to get out of the car and jump off the cliff by themselves. The loss of that beautiful car is the real tragedy. As for Thelma and Louise? Good riddance.
